rsbNotes.title: Acts 10:24
rsbNotes.text: 10:24 the following day. It took the group two days to travel thirty miles from Joppa to Caesarea.

rsbNotes.title: Acts 10:25
rsbNotes.text:
10:25 Peter entered. Peter was now willing to enter the house of a Gentile (v. 28).

fell down at his feet and worshiped him. Cornelius was overawed at Peter’s presence; he had been instructed by God to send for the apostle.

rsbNotes.title: Acts 10:28
rsbNotes.text: 10:28 God has shown me. He refers to the vision he had seen (v. 15).

rsbNotes.title: Acts 10:34
rsbNotes.text: 10:34 God shows no partiality. The gospel is for both Jews and Gentiles (1:8; Rom. 1:16).

rsbNotes.title: Acts 10:36
rsbNotes.text:
10:36 preaching good news of peace through Jesus Christ. The peace of reconciliation with God through the blood of Jesus, our peace (Eph. 2:13, 14).

Lord of all. Jesus is Lord of both Jews and Gentiles.

rsbNotes.title: Acts 10:44
rsbNotes.text: 10:44 the Holy Spirit fell on all. They were anointed by the Spirit’s power and were praising God and speaking in tongues (v. 46).

rsbNotes.title: Acts 10:45
rsbNotes.text: 10:45 the circumcised . . . were amazed. It was difficult for strict Jews who had not seen Peter’s vision to realize that God did not show favoritism in His offer.

rsbNotes.title: Acts 10:48
rsbNotes.text: 10:48 in the name of Jesus Christ. Forgiveness of sins is through the name of Jesus (v. 43).
